title: Liquid Labor - Freelancer Contracts
description: プラットフォームベースの製品やサービスへの急速な移行により、複雑なレイヤーが追加され、ユーザーに不利益をもたらしています。

f6_assessments.q0: Its not really clear what this problem is solving. The proposer has not explained in their proposal but linked to a medium article. It appears it is a simple smart contract where the freelancer tells the client they have done part of a job and the client approves and releases or transfers funds. What does this add over the freelancer and client simply sending funds directly to a wallet at each stage? Is it that total funds are held in escrow first? What if there is an issue, who mediates to release escrowed funds from the smart contract or are they locked there in perpetuity? It would be good to have a clearer explanation of the benefits to both sides using this contract.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer appears to have already developed the code in Solidity and will port to Plutus for Cardano. This is likely to be delivered if funded. The linked medium article mentions perhaps building a better UI, but this is not mentioned in the proposal. 
Initially I was inclined to give the proposer the benefit of the doubt. After looking into all the other proposals they have submitted however, I am not so sure. This proposer has proposed or co-proposed a number of other project with little details and/or funding requests such as:
Pharo ACM - $1
Proof of Insurance - no details
communitybond.io Integrate- no details
Community Bond -Loyalty Rewards - no details
Community Bond - Metadata - no details
Trade Finance and Credit Insurance - minimal details
Pharo ACM - $5
Endangered Language Preservation - no details
Locating Culture - no details
NAGchi - no details
NAGchi Cares - no details
f6_assessments.q2: No timeline or clear deliverables have been mentioned thus making it hard to audit. The proposer has not defined what success would be. Perhaps some goals on number of users, contracts etc?

f6_assessments.q0: With mentions of solidity, and then no mentions of a bridge between ETH, Cardano, and any details about how this works on the Cardano chain I do not see how this proposal contributes to Cardano's DeFi ecosystem. This connection, however, may have just been omitted.
f6_assessments.q1:
Quasar seems to be taking a shotgun, rather than a scalpel, approach to these proposals. They have so many proposals in Fund6 I am imagining their strategy as one of presenting more quantity of proposals, in hopes some will be advanced, but the quality of this one, at least, is lacking. It would have been better to propose less number of items, and have focused on providing more information about the items.
From this proposal I have trouble seeing the team involved, and need more to go on in order to know this implementation. In this example, where does solidity come in? How will it be encapsulated on the Cardano chain?
f6_assessments.q2: There just is not enough information present, and in the correct form, to see a plan that can be executed to the point of success. Metrics are needed to know what to define as a success with this proposal. A roadmap of milestones, or user stories if Agile developed: would be key to see a route to success, but just am not seeing this needed information.

f6_assessments.q0:
Draft proposal.

The problem and solution are not clear. There is an article explaining a payment intermediation model for smart contracts, but the concept does not indicate any direct relationship with the challenge.

There is no plan and no items allowing to measure the impact of the proposal.

I recommend that the problem, solution and their relationship to the challenge be communicated more clearly.
f6_assessments.q1:
Draft proposal.

There is no information on the technical qualification of the proposer for the development of smart contracts.

There is no detailed plan, no roadmap, no milestones, no metrics, no KPIs and no budget breakdown.

There is a rationale that explains the idea at a high level, but the purpose of using blockchain for this application is not clear.

This smart contract cited requires a dispute model to work and this was not mentioned in the proposal.

A contractor may claim that the service was not satisfactory and request the release of funds. Who will determine whether the terms of the contract are met or not? This falls into the oracle problem, so there would be a need for mediation. Service contracts can have many nuances and the dispute can become a complex process. This is a basic concept that must be defined in order to know if the idea is viable or not. If the mediation process is too complex, costly, or irregular, the project's value proposition may not be justified for some types of contracts.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is no clarity in the description of the problem, the solution and how they will address the challenge.

There is no roadmap, no goals, no metrics, no KPIs, no budget allocation or any other details that allow auditability.

I recommend including these items, as per the documentation indicated for creating Catalyst proposals.

f6_assessments.q0: I wish more effort would have been put into this. Just posting an article with a couple of sentences does not fulfill the necessity for a good proposal. The useful this idea can POTENTIALLY be, it has to be properly adressed for it to be effective.
f6_assessments.q1: No plan for implementation is given. The experirnce of the proposer can be doubted as the proposer proposes too many ideas in toally different areas.

f6_assessments.q0: Appears to be a valid use case which already exists in other blockchain networks. Therefore, the problem identified is sound and represents an opportunity to scale up Cardano's DeFi ecosystem. Proposal could include further examples to cast light on the importance of this proposal making an impact. I note that the author refers to 'we' but has included only themselves as proposer.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal lacks the necessary checklist to authenticate experience of the proposer to implement the project. I am inclined to think that some experience is certainly present and that they certainly have the skillset required to research the intended outcome. The proposal would have benefitted from further clarification of the team members and examples of previous work undertaken. The plan seems a little light on detail which makes assessment of successful implementation difficult. This proposal would be greatly improved with tangible examples.
f6_assessments.q2: The concept appears sound but lacks sufficient information to audit the progress and ultimately success. The proposer may have an excellent idea/concept, the budget seems reasonable but the proposal has too many gaps re: roadmap, explanation of stages and/or examples to be assessed higher at this stage. I would recommend formation of a team or collaboration with community members to further progress this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Ths proposal does not present a plan or a problem that is related to scaling up the cardano DeFi development. t is rather a random statement that freelancers need to use smart contracts for payment.
f6_assessments.q1: Insurance and risk management is not the proper experience we want to see developing defi. The proposer has also stated contradicting experience as well. They seem to be doing this on their own or decided not to share any info on any of the team or their organization.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal provides no relevant information in order to audit the progress and success of the proposal.  There is no plan laid out, nor is their an intent for the budget. They do not lay out metrics to measure for success either.

f6_assessments.q0: It is undeniable that making the exchange of development services easier and more fluid through smart contracts is a contribution to the development of DeFi. The description of the problem would, however, deserve to be detailed and quantified. For example, it would be interesting to know how much the smartcontract which allows the exchange of work in a more liquid way is used on Ethereum.
f6_assessments.q1:
The freelancer smartcontract is an existing Ethereum Smartcontract, provided in solidity. It is well described and with source code can be found on author's github repository. 
The principles of the freelancer smartcontract are well defined.
The author does not provide evidence of computing science experience, or of previous development, unless he is also the author of the solidity smart contract, which I cannot tell for sure.
f6_assessments.q2:
The use of the requested fundings is not detailed, nor are the projet milestones or delivery date. 
To enable a regular monitoring of the development of the project, I recommend the proposer to at least provide an estimated delivery date and details about the development steps.
